Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The Development of a Framework for Quantifying Hydrologic Surface Connectivity of a Coastal River-Floodplain System

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This doctoral dissertation research project will develop a framework for analyzing the degree of connection between a river and its floodplain considering its hydrologic conditions, geomorphic patterns and processes, and the distribution of vegetation within the floodplain. The productive and diverse nature of rivers and their floodplains and the ecosystem services they provide is greatly influenced by and dependent on river-floodplain connectivity. Losses in river-floodplain connectivity due to human impacts across the globe has been well documented, but quantifying these losses has been complicated by a lack of formal framework for quantifying landscape connectivity within floodplains. This project will develop a framework that combines the hydrologic surface connectivity concept with graph/network theory. Such a framework will help advance scientific understanding of river-floodplain processes as it will consistently quantify measures and ultimately permit these systems to be categorized and compared using a standard approach. Moreover, this more standard approach will find a useful application in the development of environmental flow policies for many rivers. As a Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement award, this award also will provide support to enable a promising student to establish a strong independent research career.

Graph theory has been widely used within the fields of hydrology, geomorphology, and ecology to characterize connectivity and its attributes within landscape systems. This makes graph theory well-suited for the development of a framework for characterizing river-floodplain systems using a landscape connectivity perspective. The two objectives of this project are: (1) to quantitatively determine how hydrologic surface connectivity varies within a specific river-floodplain system for the four methods (morphometric analyses, field-based direct measurements, image analyses, and numerical modeling) commonly used to analyze hydrologic surface connectivity; and (2) to evaluate the similarities and differences amongst the family of hydrologic surface connectivity indicators and to determine the effectiveness with which each method captures attributes of the riverine landscape system. The first objective will be addressed by applying graph theoretical measures for quantifying landscape connectivity to estimates of hydrologic surface connectivity determined using field data, imagery analysis, and modelling techniques. These have been used in the past, but not consistently. The second objective will be addressed using results from the first objective in order to compare estimates of connectivity and its attributes for each approach used in determining hydrologic surface connectivity. The similarities and differences amongst the connectivity measures will be used to determine how well each method for analyzing hydrologic surface connectivity captures aspects of river-floodplain process. A case study of the Mission River in Texas will be used to develop this framework and determine its utility.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has built towards the development of a framework for analyzing the degree and duration of connection between a river and its floodplain with regard to hydrologic conditions, geomorphic patterns and processes, and the geographical distribution of soil units and riparian vegetation within the floodplain. River-floodplain connectivity is often described using hydrologic surface connectivity concepts that are generally concerned with how surface water has aided the transfer of energy, matter, organisms, and information between components of the river-floodplain system. The productive and diverse nature of river-floodplain environments is greatly influenced by river-floodplain connectivity. Losses in river-floodplain connectivity due to human impacts for rivers across the globe has been well documented in the literature, but quantifying these losses has been complicated by the lack of a formal framework for quantifying landscape connectivity within floodplains. The specific objectives pursued by this project have highlighted and refined the use of some underappreciated tools and methods that should be incorporated into any framework for analyzing connectivity within riverine landscapes. The wide adoption of these tools and methods will help advance scientific understanding of river-floodplain process in that they will allow river-floodplain connectivity to be quantified using consistent measures and ultimately allow for river-floodplain systems to be categorized and compared using standard approaches. Moreover, the geomorphic properties of floodplains are rarely considered within environmental flow policies and the tools and methods highlighted in this project will help bring these properties into consideration in that they will relate river-floodplain connectivity to streamflow properties commonly named in environmental policies such as flow depth and discharge.

Graph theory and field-based data loggers have been widely used within the fields of hydrology, geomorphology, and ecology to characterize connectivity and its attributes within landscape systems. This indicates that graph theory and field-based data loggers are tools that are well-suited for the development of a framework for characterizing river-floodplain systems using a landscape connectivity perspective. This project had two main objectives: (1) quantitatively determine how hydrologic surface connectivity varies within the Mission River-Floodplain system amongst methods commonly used to analyze hydrologic surface connectivity; and (2) evaluate similarities and differences amongst the family of hydrologic surface connectivity indicators and determine the effectiveness with which each method captures attributes of the riverine landscape system. The first objective was addressed by applying graph theoretical analyzes and field-based data loggers in a manner that allows landscape connectivity to be quantified using estimates of hydrologic surface connectivity determined using terrain analysis and hydrodynamic modeling. While the use of these methods for analyzing flood inundation has been pursued in the literature, these methods have not been consistently applied in a manner that allows landscape connectivity to be described. The second objective has been addressed by using results from the first objective in order to compare estimates of connectivity and its attributes for each approach used in determining hydrologic surface connectivity. The similarities and differences amongst the connectivity measures is used to determine how well each method for analyzing hydrologic surface connectivity captures aspects of river-floodplain process. A case study of Mission River on the Coastal Bend of Texas was used to refine the use of the aforementioned tools and determine their utility in a largely undisturbed river-floodplain environment with a dynamic flow regime. We conclude that graph theory is a useful tool for quantifying landscape connectivity across space with the spatial pattern of connectivity resembling the scale-free graph model that has been widely studied in the literature. Moreover, hydrologic surface connectivity is controlled by flood inundation and we found that hydrodynamic modeling provides the most accurate predictions of flood inundation; thus graph theoretical estimates of landscape connectivity are most accurate when combined with flood predictions from hydrodynamic modeling. We also conclude that field-based data loggers provide a useful tool for quantifying the temporal dynamics of landscape connectivity and they also provide a means for determining if the flood-waters originated from riverine, marine, precipitation, and/or groundwater sources if the data loggers being used record data on water temperature and conductivity. This project has helped us make important steps towards the development of a framework for quantifying hydrologic surface connectivity that is lacking within the field of river science. The tools and framework that we are building towards here will increase our understanding river-floodplain landscapes and inform the management of these critical environments.
